pros: Strong company culture, good work-life balance (dependent on team), friendly and inclusive culture, above average pay for a graduate scheme
cons:
I would like to add to the review left on 29 June 2020 for the Commercial Banking (CMB) Graduate Programme to reflect that the sentiment described was definitely not an isolated case - a lot of graduates had similar experiences.

Removing subjective judgments the CMB Graduate Scheme has been plagued by numerous problems - I would address two in this review. First, mismanagement. Across different cohorts graduates have been told at the very last minute of “sudden business changes” which required re-assignments from value-adding placements to basic call centre roles, and in at least two instances even a mandatory extension of at least six months to the 18-months programme graduates signed on to. What graduates signed on to was an 18-month national mobility situation, not what inevitability transpired as described. It was widely felt that there was complete disregard for any personal circumstances, where everyone was expected to accept this out-of-contract, unforeseen arrangement without protest (for any protest received admonishments for graduates being “ungrateful” and “entitled” and “having bad attitudes”), uproot themselves and resolve any logistical or financial issues at last-minute notice, with minimum to no support. 

Second, under-qualified graduate managers. While the above described could be explained as top-down instructions outside of the graduate team’s control being poorly executed by the graduate managers, the managers’ lack of CMB knowledge and lack of initiative to remedy that after years of being in the role was inexcusable. This was particularly problematic was because graduate placements were allocated by graduate managers, who screened placement applications. Graduates were told to write their applications in laymen terms, because if graduates included “technical banking terms”, the graduate managers would not be able to understand the application and would disregard those parts as irrelevant. This greatly affected the chances of graduates being placed in teams that best fit their skills and desired career paths. 

Numerous other issues could be raised with ample examples which would result in this review being unreadably long. I hope, however, that the detailed examples given in this review could give some context as to how the CMB graduate scheme was run. 

I could confirm here, however, that as stated in the 29 June 2020 review, favouritism and preferential treatments were existent, and that the high dropout rate of graduates particularly in the past year, as well as graduates taking time off due to the graduate programme compromising graduates’ mental health were true.

pros: - Pension and benefits are good
cons:
The Swansea ‘contact-centre’ is one of the most unwelcoming and toxic work environments I’ve ever experienced. 

From the get-go you are treated as just a number by management and ‘colleagues’ around you. 9 other people started the same time as myself and within the first three months 6 had resigned largely due to job dissatisfaction. The training group I joined were all herded on the telephones as quickly as possibly with abject and minimal training (3 days out of the 20 days training was spent covering a topic which is not relevant to the role). 

The training provided was by a third-party company and not HSBC, therefore, information that was being provided in training was out-of-date and not in line with current policy and procedure.

Myself and others had first-hand experiences of harassment and bullying from selective colleagues and managers. One particular incident I remember is a ‘senior’ manager trying to make an example of me in front of the office floor of 15/20 people. I cannot give the specific example because it will probably identify who I am , and I’m confident the managers will have a good-laugh about how they tried to belittle me . This example is just one of many within the Swansea ‘call-centre’ of management being pedantic about trivial issues instead of managing staff properly and providing a high level of customer service. 

After this particular incident I lost all respect for management within the ‘call-centre’ and immediately started looking for alternative employment. 

Conflicting information from employee to employee! Because the organisation is so large, it’s hard to have consistent messages communicated. I found that i’d come in one morning and one senior is telling you one thing and another manager another, which in a customer service role can lead to very irate and annoyed customers if you’re not providing accurate information.

Finally, I found the job to be repetitive and soul- destroying as you deal with 40/50 calls a day, the large majority of these customers are already irate before you speak to them because they’ve been waiting in a queue for 40-50 minutes (on a good day). 

This job could be for some people but not for myself, the ‘call-centre’ environment has a low ‘ceiling’ when it comes to progression and pay, the mortgage department was littered with employees who had been in the job for 10-15 years and were still earning £17,500, for people with ambition I would say the ‘call-centre’ is not for you.
